description: Primes formed by the initial digits of the decimal expansion of Pi.
comments: The next term consists of the first 16208 digits of Pi and is too large to show here (see A060421). Ed T. Prothro found this probable prime in 2001.A naive probabilistic argument suggests that the sequence is infinite. [_Michael Kleber_, Jun 23 2004]
references: N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: Ed T. Prothro, How I Found the Next Pi Prime [Broken link]

formula: a(n)=floor(10^(A060421(n)-1)*A000796), where A000796 is the constant Pi = 3.14159... _- _M. F. Hasler_, Sep 02 2013
